body:
Problem:
restart hangs when nvim was started with stdin input, "-" marker stays in v:argv, causing the restarted instance to block reading from stdin.

Solution:
filter out the "-" argument when rebuilding v:argv during restart. Stdin content is ephemeral and shouldn't be re-read after restart.

Fix #34417

comment_data.body: would it be more reliable to use `VV_ARGF` , after we merge https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35889 ?

On Windows, seems like stdin is treated as a tty rather than a pipe, so `nvim -` does not create the same read-only stdin buffer as on Unix. The test is about filtering "-" from v:argv, not the exact UI state,  it's still failed on Windows so skip on Windows

comment_data.body: yes, but "-" should be in the file arguments, right? i'm wondering if there is a potential for a "false positive" here, and using VV_ARGF would avoid that.

ye good point. The false positive case is `nvim -- -` where `-` is a filename. VV_ARGF stores file arguments expanded to their full paths. So a file literally named `-` will be stored as something like `/path/to/-`, whereas the stdin marker `-` will never appear in VV_ARGF at all. The cleanest fix would be to expose `had_stdin_file` as a vim variable (e.g. `v:stdin`) set during startup, so ex_restart can distinguish the stdin marker from a file named `-`.  implement that instead?
in the case of `nvim -s -` , the `-s` also needs to be removed

comment_regular_data.body: On Unix systems, should `/dev/stdin` also be filtered?
`/dev/stdin` is treated as a regular file path, not a special stdin marker.
